title: Linked Open Data Driven Game Generation

author: Rob Warren, Institute for Big Data Analytics, Dalhousie University

segmentation: I would like to just start and take my my Co presenters for letting me swap with them.
I apologize this transit strike is causing me some grief.
So.
The question that this talk is about is how do we deal with very large collections of data?
We've gone out.
We've created these vocabularies.
These very large databases of fax things places and they have different precisions, difference accuracies and different topics.
But it's a very complex data structure and by far and wide.
The only thing that we've come up with to really visualize it are these graphs.
And this is a representation.
This is actually a plot of my military ontology.
It's not all that large is a few thousand terms, several thousand properties, and you quickly get this blob of ink where nothing is really understandable from it.
You need a secondary search system to narrow down your search to a certain part of the ontology, and then you actually know what's going on.
But what is apparent from our colleagues in the other signs such as history or computational journalism or computational history, is that they're very interested in using their data.
They know that the data is out there, but they don't necessarily have the tooling to get to it, nor did they necessarily have the database training to actually write their own tools.
And this is creating some frustrations and getting getting the data that they know.
Is there an it creates these bizarre one liners such as?
I can't tell you what I'm looking for, but I'll know what I'm looking at when I find it.
And from that requirements perspective, that's very annoying.
Complicated to us also.
So my own problem came about when I started working on this linked Open Data project about the First World War.
It's at the top right of the linked open data Cloud, and there is a small ecosystem of World War One linked open data projects that's being created slowly.
Did they give you an idea?
The scale at which ideal this is a plot of all the Geo points within the database.
It's about 40 to 50 million triples, and it covers ships, locations, military bases, people involved, events and so on and so forth.
And after spending a few years creating data using scripts on a very large scale, the question is well.
What do we do with it to the majority of people we deal with the sum of data analysis is to use a spreadsheet.
It's tabular, it's 2 dimensional.
It's easy to work with.
And it hasn't changed much since guys busy calc in the late 70s.
The problem is when we give them a graph, it doesn't really fit that paradigm anymore.
And getting the analysis done becomes complicated.
So these are representations of the trenches of the Western Front, and it's fairly complex.
There is a trench the width of the trench where the individual data points of the trenches are.
There are several 100 trenches covered by several 100 Maps over the course of four years.
Each tranche has multiple mulligans in Geometry's over several dates, and each tranche has several names and labels applied by different armies as they move in and out of the position.
Besides making a very nice graphic plot for historian, it's very hard to hit for historian to get to the data within this within this database and make it an appropriate analysis.
So the question is, how can you really use this data represented in terms that a domain expert can understand without necessarily making him a database expert?
And the solution that we've looked at.
To create a T3D world.
And the reason for this is that a 3D World is intuitive.
Most of us have grown up playing computer games.
It's easy to relate to 3D objects as we see them in front of us.
Ann to as Victoria Borer pointed out earlier today, not everybody is literate.
Not everybody is literate in the same language as we are.
Therefore, if you draw a picture in front of it, it's a fairly universal representation of what's going on.
Now the representation of visualization can lie and the data is not always accurate and there has been some work in documenting how we do a representation.
So Valeria Vitali has this four point scale.
Let's say that says this is durate that we have.
This is the representation and these are the pitfalls within each situations.
But the nice thing about linked open data is that when we make a decision, we can point to the specific data source that we used to create that representation or that graphic.
That you may be aware of this, but online there is a list of museum APIs and libraries.
It's collected by marriage.
There are over 50 APIs.
Each of those APIs is unique.
None of them use a standard representation.
The nice thing about linked open data is that it's on web standards.
All of Luke and linked open data works pretty much the same.
They may have different vocabularies, but there are the same standards and it's always a sparkle endpoint.
You know what that looks like if you're trying to use multiple APIs, each new API will need another implementation to talk to it.

Hands from our perspective, linked open data is a great tool in that we can access each new data source irrespective of where it comes from or who put it together without necessarily having to rewrite the interface.
Also, I was talking about precision.
I extract map data from rasters and vectorize it.
The precision can be expected to say plus or minus 5 yards.
5 yards is fairly hard to measure on a 3D World.
The average trench will be about 2 meters deep, 1 meters wide.
If you see this from a visualization perspective, the only thing you can really tell is the aspect ratio of up versus versus side.
So maybe it's 2 meters.
Maybe it's 1.5, maybe it's 3.
From your perspective it looks reasonably accurate an we can hide certain imperfections into data just by the fact that their visualization is limited.
The first example I'd like to tell you about in terms of representing in accuracies and limited data is talking bout vegetation or threes.

Trees are actually important on this Western Front, even though they get shot at very often, there are very popular with written with Gunners and observers who uses the range Ranger shot and send out coordinates.
And to represent on the map fairly accurately, the one thing that we're missing is we don't know how large it 3 is.
We don't know what species are.
Treat three years and we don't know what shape the tree is.
So how can you build a 3D representation without knowing any of that?
And Luckily we have other linked open data sources such as the pedia that have this information.
Now this is a rough graph of what's available in DPD in terms of trees and something that I'd like to point out to you right away is some of the bizarreness of how we do.
Representation in concept San groups.
For example, here we have category Flora France.
Which is downstream from cat Flora by country.
But there is no relationship in between category floor of France and Dbpedia France.
So there is no way for me to go from my location to country to this pretty particular category that talks about that country.
So in this case, a little bit of hacking around with regular expression allows me to recover the country from DB pedia.
It's not great, it works, but it's not ideal.
At the same time.
The use of S korsan al was debated earlier in another presentation.
One of my concerns with S costs is that it's really a representation that was meant for human beings.

If you need to go down into a structure that you don't necessarily understand, even though there's a semantic relationship in between, all of those terms, each new level requires a new fetch from the database.
Latency means that any any taxonomy that's built like that that has any reasonable DEF will take quite a bit of time to go through.
From that perspective, I'm leaving much more towards Al and that it gives you the inheritance for free without you having to constantly re create a database for another level of the taxonomy.
Another aspect of linked open data is that if we can't really estimate things such as a species from a database of flora, one thing we can go out and just do it empirically.
We have the Openstreetmap leaked open Geo data.
If you have a three, we know that a tree species tends to proliferate itself nearby, so let's go.
Let's go through an samples.
All of the species of trees around this tree wait until we get a statistical convergence and take something in the 99% histogram.
Similarly, if you wish to the width of the tree, the height of the tree to currently tree.
Again, threes are social or social things.
We do a statistical.
Excuse me, we do a statistical guess based on the numbers attached to all of the other three's.
Wait until it conversion 90% accuracy and then we have our answers.
Now in our case we're looking for threes.
In 1914 the trees in 2007 are probably probably not a good idea.
Summer from our perspective we use DB pedia when there's a tree that needs to appear within within the simulation.
We simply instantiate whatever three is known to exist within that area and by clicking on it.
You'll actually get the species of tree that was statistically assigned to it.
Now there are ontologies that go a little bit deeper into it into this, and again they use the S costs.
One of the things that concerns me greatly is that we tend to create Elodie data based.
On other data set we have a lot of great alot of implicit data contained within within Dem.
So for example in bioportal there's this great ontology about using trees and flora.
However, you will never know that they're actually talking about threes because they only use the binomial Latin name for everything.
Similarly.
For the Library of Congress taxonomy.
It's obvious that there is many concept schemes that are concurrently being used here, but none of them are documented.
So if you're trying to use this in order to retrieve more information about something, you're likely to get a semantically Audie answer.
The last two aspects I'd like to talk about our culturally aware game assets.
When you create a game, there's a number of things that true into this scene.
So in this case a photograph and I placed it in a trench for demonstration purposes, but if it's in the Canadian trench, it'll take play a record that's Canadian.
If it's in the German, transit plays a record that's from the German era, and it's the same thing, but the thing reacts to where it is in time and space and plays different media.
Again, the problem is we keep using these mapping aspects an I get a data structure of this kind word as an MP3 and it says French songs.
Does that mean that the French is in French?
The song is in French.
Is it culturally French?
Or does that mean that it's interpreted in French?
So you get things bizarre like oh silent light night that exists in five different languages.
If you give me a recording, are you saying that it was originally a French song?
Or are you saying that it's recorded in French?
And this is one of the particularly interested in is game litter.
We have things lying around on the floor.
We have posters on the wall.
An all of these bizarre little things that make a simulation realistic.
Concurrently, our archives have been scanning documents for years and putting them online.
So in the game, if you're in a German trench, you get a German newspaper from 2 weeks ago.
If you're in a French trench, you get a French newspaper from 2 weeks ago.
Again, there are problems with the RDF.

the German National Library is doing a great job of trying to link all of its documents with a Jew named names, but then the question is we get places like Gumbiner which has been invaded, Re invaded, reattach to different countries.
Over the years an where that actually exists in time in space can be a bit troublesome.
Similarly, because of historical situations, we tend to separate our linked open data from the content management system.
Therefore, that makes things complicated because we need a second act to actually get the data once we found it within the database.
So I've learned over years never to run the live demo.
So this is simulation of ground fire an wanted one of the trenches near move.
And everything that you see in front of you is generated based on linked open data from the trenches to their trays to the newspapers that are a far edge corner over here.
It is not very sophisticated this time, primarily because linked open data tends to stress the memory management functions of most modern game engines.
The demo is online and you're welcome to play with it.
So this is not a new idea.
Auto Kellman worked on this in 2005 and finally 10 years after we finally have the level of data and semantic integration that we need to actually make this work in reality.

The most exciting part of it is that a lot of these top level ontologies that track things like physics an whether an object is pliable or not can be reinserted into the physics engine of the game, and we can instantiate objects that actually take on the physical properties that they're meant to without necessarily needing to write the code to do so.
There's a lot of working around that is quite annoying from an implementation point of view, but overtime I sure will fix that.
I am serious.
I one last thing that I would like to point out.
This is supposed to be the social networking.
Aspect of this present of this.
Present.
Nation.
This is a graph of what you might expect in Astana standard military organization in a trench, and there's the commanders.
Some camp managers don't like each other.
Some of them do, but from the from the person perspective, people are friends, and we know that from a social network perspective.
The social presence or social distance equates to physical.

Closeness, so in terms of simulation, if I'm trying to simulate how many people are in a trench in where they are, I don't necessarily have that data historically, but I can simulate it based on the interpretation, personal relationships that are being planned that are being reported.
If two people are friends out of a group of 100, they will tend to gravitate each other and that allows me to do the placement of individuals within a trench.
The reason, as I bring this up is I keep hearing these comments that says, oh, this particular data set is too small or not interesting enough.

For our for our benefit, and I wanted to point out that it's fine if you don't think that it's a benefit or reviews, but ten years down the line or 15 years down the line, somebody may find a use for it and it costs very little to actually generate it and leave it on the side for the time being.
So at this time I'd like to take any questions.
Cute.
Any questions?
Well, I would like to ask a question.
It's really nice to see this kind of applications and I was wondering whether you sort of from what you mentioned computational history point of view.
You can do easily other reconstructions like if it's instead of landscape elements you need to reconstruct would be buildings inside buildings.
Whether this would be as easy and whether they're in your.
Paula geez, for these to help you do in the link data there are number and ontologies to do that including the building information model.
I haven't gone to that point yet, but eventually I think we will get to it.
And again the benefit of linked open data.

Is that I focus on the First World War, but in a few years it becomes just a question of where do you want and space in time to simulate and we just pulled in more data and simulate Downtown Revival Revival guard and see what happens.
And did historians with whom you're working find it interesting to compare the social social data that you get from the graphs with the social data that you get from the simulation?

So whether this gives them some insights for different interpretation of historical events through the way people play the game, they see things much more from a command perspective, so the relationships between the different soldiers don't necessarily interest them.
Their relationships in between the commander is interesting more because of the.
Amount of paperwork and records that are kept.
So I wondered if you had like a abstraction layer from unity to link data.
Is that kind of a piece of software you have, or how tight is it with your with the whole historical framework?
So can I just grab a piece of software for the heated like data bit?
There is a very poorly written abstraction layer.
And I could speak at length about Unity, but eventually it slowly developing in that there are small bugs that need to be fixed.
But essentially once you get a cultural object written, it's extremely easy to adapt it to any time or space or location.
Hence it's the ultimate wet dream of social software engineering to say here, let's write one piece of code, never write it again, never touch it again.
It just works.
So from that perspective I'm very happy with it.
Thank you.
